body:
I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely *zero* traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?
body_html:

This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?

post.title: How do you get people to see your repo on github?

body: spread word about what it is and how to use it, and not to be rude (seeing as I don't know what repo you're talking about) but making you're projects run faster, safer, and more transparent could help, if you're really trying to get people to download then use the readme to the most of it's ability, create documentation, basically make it something that just by reading it you'd want to try it out even if you weren't interested, or maybe it's not an issue of documentation but code, seeing as the problem is downloads and not flaming comments in the issues page I'd say work on documentation, then you get the joy of being flamed in FOSS
body_html: spread word about what it is and how to use it, and not to be rude (seeing as I don't know what repo you're talking about) but making you're projects run faster, safer, and more transparent could help, if you're really trying to get people to download then use the readme to the most of it's ability, create documentation, basically make it something that just by reading it you'd want to try it out even if you weren't interested, or maybe it's not an issue of documentation but code, seeing as the problem is downloads and not flaming comments in the issues page I'd say work on documentation, then you get the joy of being flamed in FOSS

body:
I have multiple different repos that most people have found pretty cool so far: https://github.com/CrystalVulpine?tab=repositories

However my insights page is showing no traffic except from ruqqus. I wouldn't have thought anything of it but I checked the download count for other people's repos that aren't mentioned anywhere else at all and they all get a decent amount of traffic just from existing, like I said about 10-20 downloads per month or two per repo on average. The authors are not well known or have followers either. So it seems like their repos are showing up on some kind of explore/discovery pages and mine aren't for some reason.
body_html:
I have multiple different repos that most people have found pretty cool so far: https://github.com/CrystalVulpine?tab=repositories

However my insights page is showing no traffic except from ruqqus. I wouldn't have thought anything of it but I checked the download count for other people's repos that aren't mentioned anywhere else at all and they all get a decent amount of traffic just from existing, like I said about 10-20 downloads per month or two per repo on average. The authors are not well known or have followers either. So it seems like their repos are showing up on some kind of explore/discovery pages and mine aren't for some reason.

body:
I have done that, the problem is my repos aren't showing up anywhere so no one sees them anyway. But it seems that other users' repos *are* because they get a small amount of traffic just by existing. I was able to check the download counts and mine is much lower despite broadcasting my stuff on Ruqqus a lot, so github users must be able to discover repos naturally but mine aren't included in that for some reason. That would make sense if github thinks I'm a spam account.

Here's my repos: https://github.com/CrystalVulpine?tab=repositories

That would make sense if github thinks I'm a spam account.

author.bio: It is obvious that CaptianObvious can't spell.
author.bio_html: It is obvious that CaptianObvious can't spell.

body: Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things.  Stability is important.  Also needs to be things that people want to use.  A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing.  Not too many on GitHub looking for games.  Honestly I've never downloaded game from GitHub, but a library for doing path finding, or image processing, sure.
body_html: Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things. Stability is important. Also needs to be things that people want to use. A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing. Not too many on GitHub looking for games. Honestly I've never downloaded game from GitHub, but a library for doing path finding, or image processing, sure.

author.bio:

body:
> Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things.

Most of the repos I'm looking at are still on prereleases. [One got four stars and it doesn't even do anything yet](https://github.com/gingkathfox/ruqqjs).

> A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing.

Most of the other people's repos aren't libraries. They're usually small apps that perform a very niche function. And only one of my repos is a game. It honestly feels like github is hiding me from potential traffic because it thinks I'm spam or something. Maybe since I have a very new account the systems don't trust me and it'll take a while for that to wear off, because I'm definitely not getting any views from github itself but other people are.

I also noticed that my repos are always further down in the search results than others' when searching for the same topic, for example: https://github.com/search?q=ruqqus

The repos from all the other major ruqqus contributors are on the first page, and mine is buried near the bottom of the second one. Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

It's not too big of a deal but it will hurt my ability to develop for a wide range of users.
body_html:
Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things.

Most of the repos I'm looking at are still on prereleases. One got four stars and it doesn't even do anything yet.

A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing.

Most of the other people's repos aren't libraries. They're usually small apps that perform a very niche function. And only one of my repos is a game. It honestly feels like github is hiding me from potential traffic because it thinks I'm spam or something. Maybe since I have a very new account the systems don't trust me and it'll take a while for that to wear off, because I'm definitely not getting any views from github itself but other people are.

I also noticed that my repos are always further down in the search results than others' when searching for the same topic, for example: https://github.com/search?q=ruqqus

The repos from all the other major ruqqus contributors are on the first page, and mine is buried near the bottom of the second one. Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

It's not too big of a deal but it will hurt my ability to develop for a wide range of users.

body:
This is my last answer because I’m tired now with your inability to accept what people tell you:

> Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

No, they do not do this. Add features, fix bugs, release something. 

> It's not too big of a deal but it will hurt my ability to develop for a wide range of users.

No, it won’t hurt your ability to type on a keyboard, they are not the police.

Stop looking at other projects, look at yourself and make progresses.
body_html:
This is my last answer because I’m tired now with your inability to accept what people tell you:

Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

guild.name: Programming

parent.body:
> Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things.

Most of the repos I'm looking at are still on prereleases. [One got four stars and it doesn't even do anything yet](https://github.com/gingkathfox/ruqqjs).

> A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing.

Most of the other people's repos aren't libraries. They're usually small apps that perform a very niche function. And only one of my repos is a game. It honestly feels like github is hiding me from potential traffic because it thinks I'm spam or something. Maybe since I have a very new account the systems don't trust me and it'll take a while for that to wear off, because I'm definitely not getting any views from github itself but other people are.

I also noticed that my repos are always further down in the search results than others' when searching for the same topic, for example: https://github.com/search?q=ruqqus

The repos from all the other major ruqqus contributors are on the first page, and mine is buried near the bottom of the second one. Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

It's not too big of a deal but it will hurt my ability to develop for a wide range of users.

body: Most likely has to do with a black box searching algorithm that is focusing on number of commits or download count, it will probably get better as more people check it out

body:
I doubt it. For example ruqqus-plus is behind even ruqqyou and it's a much larger project that probably gets quite a bit of attention (from ruqqus, it's not lucky enough to be visible from github itself). But ruqqJS is a 3-commit project that doesn't even do anything yet and was placed at the very top immediately. I would say the download count and views and stars and such are the *consequence* of where it appears in search, not the cause.

Looking at the history of the repos, it looks like where it appears in the search results has more to do with who you are than anything else. I've noticed that the same people always get the same patterns of traffic and positions in search results for all their repos. How this is determined I have no idea, but it seems like that's how it's working. On reddit, I made the front page a few times and after that all my posts were always more visible than before and reaching the front page was easier. Then I changed accounts and it became harder again. I wouldn't doubt that github is doing something similar.
body_html:
I doubt it. For example ruqqus-plus is behind even ruqqyou and it's a much larger project that probably gets quite a bit of attention (from ruqqus, it's not lucky enough to be visible from github itself). But ruqqJS is a 3-commit project that doesn't even do anything yet and was placed at the very top immediately. I would say the download count and views and stars and such are the consequence of where it appears in search, not the cause.

Looking at the history of the repos, it looks like where it appears in the search results has more to do with who you are than anything else. I've noticed that the same people always get the same patterns of traffic and positions in search results for all their repos. How this is determined I have no idea, but it seems like that's how it's working. On reddit, I made the front page a few times and after that all my posts were always more visible than before and reaching the front page was easier. Then I changed accounts and it became harder again. I wouldn't doubt that github is doing something similar.
